questions.text: Purest water in nature is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rain water. Rain water is considered the purest water in nature because it is initially collected as vapor from water bodies and undergoes condensation in the atmosphere. Since it has no contact with contaminants on the ground, it is free from impurities such as salts, minerals, and microbes. However, rainwater can pick up pollutants as it falls through the atmosphere, but in its purest form, it is considered the cleanest form of water. Incorrect Options: A. River water – River water contains various impurities, including minerals, organic matter, and pollutants from the surrounding environment. It is often contaminated with human activities, agricultural runoff, and industrial discharges, making it far less pure than rainwater. C. Deep well – Deep well water may be relatively cleaner than surface water, but it still contains dissolved minerals and may have contaminants depending on the geological formation. It is also susceptible to pollution if the aquifer is not protected. D. Impounding reservoirs – Impounding reservoirs often collect water from rivers or streams, which can introduce sediments, bacteria, and other pollutants. Water in reservoirs is treated to make it suitable for consumption, but it is not as pure as rainwater.

choices.text: Free chlorine is released in water after break point
Chlorine demand is the amount needed to kill bacteria oxidize organic matter and neutralize ammonia
1 ppm free chlorine should be present in water after break point has reached
Contact period of 1 hour is necessary

questions.text: All the following statements are true about break point chlorination, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1 ppm free chlorine should be present in water after break point has reached. Incorrect Options: 1 ppm free chlorine should be present in water after break point has reached – This statement is incorrect because, at the break point chlorination, the chlorine dose added is typically sufficient to oxidize ammonia and organic matter, as well as disinfect the water. However, the requirement is not necessarily for 1 ppm of free chlorine to remain. The exact amount of free chlorine present after break point depends on the chlorine demand and the initial quality of the water, but it is not a fixed 1 ppm. Incorrect Options: A. Free chlorine is released in water after break point – This statement is true. After the break point is reached, free chlorine is released in the water, and it becomes available to disinfect the water effectively. B. Chlorine demand is the amount needed to kill bacteria, oxidize organic matter, and neutralize ammonia – This statement is true. Chlorine demand refers to the amount of chlorine required to neutralize contaminants such as bacteria, organic matter, and ammonia in water. D. Contact period of 1 hour is necessary – This statement is true. A contact period of around 1 hour is generally recommended after reaching the break point chlorination to ensure that chlorine has sufficient time to react with the contaminants and disinfect the water properly.

questions.text: Nitrates in excess of may cause infantile methaemoglobinaemia:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 50 mg/l. Incorrect Options: 50 mg/l – Nitrates in water, when present in concentrations greater than 50 mg/l, can pose a risk for infantile methaemoglobinaemia (also known as "blue baby syndrome"). This condition occurs when nitrates in the water are converted to nitrites, which then interfere with the ability of hemoglobin to carry oxygen. Infants are particularly vulnerable to this condition, as their bodies are not fully capable of processing excess nitrates. Incorrect Options: A. 15 mg/l – 15 mg/l is far below the threshold that is known to cause infantile methaemoglobinaemia. Although higher nitrate levels can still affect health, this concentration is not typically associated with the onset of this condition. B. 25 mg/l – Similarly, 25 mg/l is still below the harmful threshold. While it is always important to minimize nitrate levels in drinking water, this concentration is not considered to cause significant risk of methaemoglobinaemia. C. 35 mg/l – Again, 35 mg/l is not considered to cause infantile methaemoglobinaemia. The generally accepted threshold for concern is 50 mg/l, which is why this option is not correct.

questions.text: All the following provide evidence of faecal pollution except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cl. tetani. Explanation of Correct Response: Cl. tetani – Clostridium tetani, the bacteria responsible for tetanus, is not typically used as an indicator of fecal pollution. It is a pathogen that can be found in soil, animal manure, and human feces, but its presence is not specifically related to recent fecal contamination in water sources. Tetanus is more of a concern due to wounds than as an indicator of waterborne contamination. Incorrect Options: A. Faecal streptococci – Faecal streptococci are bacteria commonly found in the intestines of warm-blooded animals. They are used as indicators of fecal contamination in water. Their presence suggests that the water has been contaminated by human or animal waste. B. Coliform – Coliforms, especially Escherichia coli, are widely used as indicators of fecal contamination. Their presence in water typically indicates that the water has been contaminated with fecal matter, potentially containing harmful pathogens. D. Enteropathogenic virus – Enteropathogenic viruses (such as enteric viruses) are commonly found in feces and can be transmitted through contaminated water. Their presence is a direct indicator of fecal contamination and the potential for waterborne diseases.

questions.text: Per capita allowance for urban area of water per day is recommended at:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 150-200 lit. 150-200 lit – The recommended per capita water allowance for urban areas is typically in the range of 150-200 liters per day. This higher water allowance accounts for the increased demand in urban areas, where water usage is higher due to factors such as domestic needs, sanitation, and industrial purposes. Additionally, urban populations tend to have greater access to piped water and sanitation services, further increasing the per capita consumption. Incorrect Options: A. 70-80 lit – 70-80 liters per day is generally considered insufficient for urban areas. This range is closer to what might be appropriate for rural or less-developed areas where water usage is typically lower due to limited infrastructure and different lifestyles. B. 80-120 lit – 80-120 liters is also on the lower end and may be more suitable for rural areas or small towns where the demand for water is not as high as in large urban centers. In an urban setting, this would likely be inadequate for the needs of the population. C. 120-150 lit – 120-150 liters might be a reasonable estimate for smaller urban areas or suburban settings, but it is generally lower than the recommended per capita water allowance for larger, more developed cities where the water demand is higher.

questions.text: Recommended standard for bacterial water quality in small community supplies is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) No E. coli in 100 ml. No E. coli in 100 ml – The recommended standard for bacterial water quality in small community supplies is to have no E. coli in 100 ml of water. E. coli is a specific indicator of fecal contamination, and its presence in drinking water is a strong sign that the water may contain harmful pathogens. Ensuring there is no E. coli is critical for safe drinking water and to prevent waterborne diseases. Incorrect Options: A. No coliform – While no coliform in water is an ideal standard, it is generally not considered a practical target for routine water quality monitoring in small community supplies. Coliforms are a broader group of bacteria, and their presence does not always directly indicate fecal contamination, whereas the presence of E. coli is a more specific and reliable indicator of recent fecal contamination. C. Coliform less than 10/100 ml – A limit of less than 10 coliforms per 100 ml may be used as a guideline in some contexts, but it is less specific than focusing on E. coli. Coliform bacteria include a wide range of species, and while their presence suggests possible contamination, their concentration does not directly correlate to the same level of risk as E. coli. D. Coliform less than 5/100 ml – Similar to Option C, this is another standard for coliform levels, but it is not as specific or stringent as requiring no E. coli. Focusing on E. coli as an indicator provides more direct assurance of water safety and health.

questions.text: Temporary hardness of water is primarily due to the presence of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Calcium and magnesium bicarbonates. Calcium and magnesium bicarbonates – Temporary hardness of water is primarily due to the presence of calcium and magnesium bicarbonates (Ca(HCO3)2 and Mg(HCO3)2). This type of hardness is called "temporary" because it can be removed by boiling the water. When boiled, calcium and magnesium bicarbonates decompose into insoluble carbonates, which precipitate out of the water, thus reducing the hardness. Incorrect Options: A. Calcium and magnesium sulphates – Calcium and magnesium sulphates contribute to permanent hardness, not temporary hardness. Sulfate salts of calcium and magnesium do not precipitate upon boiling, so they cannot be removed by boiling the water. B. Calcium and magnesium chlorides – Calcium and magnesium chlorides also contribute to permanent hardness. Similar to sulfates, chlorides do not precipitate when water is boiled, and thus cannot be removed by boiling. D. Calcium and magnesium nitrates – Calcium and magnesium nitrates also cause permanent hardness. Like the chlorides and sulfates, these salts do not precipitate upon boiling, so they cannot be removed through boiling.

questions.text: Horrock’s apparatus estimates:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chlorine demand. Chlorine demand – Horrock’s apparatus is used to estimate chlorine demand, which is the amount of chlorine required to disinfect water, considering both the chlorine needed to neutralize impurities and the chlorine required to react with pollutants in the water. The apparatus is used in water treatment to determine how much chlorine should be added to meet the required disinfection standards. Incorrect Options: A. Free chlorine – Free chlorine refers to the chlorine present in water that is available to disinfect, either as chlorine gas or hypochlorous acid (HOCl). Horrock’s apparatus does not specifically estimate free chlorine, but rather the total chlorine demand. B. Combined chlorine – Combined chlorine is the chlorine that has reacted with contaminants in the water, forming chloramines. Horrock’s apparatus does not directly estimate combined chlorine, but it helps estimate the chlorine demand, which indirectly accounts for both free and combined chlorine. C. (A) + (B) – This option suggests that Horrock’s apparatus estimates the sum of free and combined chlorine. While the apparatus helps to estimate the chlorine demand, it does not directly measure the specific levels of free or combined chlorine separately. Instead, it focuses on the total chlorine demand needed for water treatment.

choices.text: Free and combined chlorine in water ammonia content in water

questions.text: Ortho toluidine test is used to determine:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Free and combined chlorine in water. Free and combined chlorine in water – The Ortho-toluidine test is used to determine both free chlorine (the chlorine available for disinfection) and combined chlorine (chlorine that has reacted with contaminants to form chloramines) in water. The test uses the reaction of ortho-toluidine with chlorine in the water to produce a color change, which is then measured to estimate the chlorine content. Incorrect Options: A. Nitrates in water – The ortho-toluidine test is not used to determine nitrates in water. Nitrates are typically measured using methods like colorimetry with reagents specific to nitrate ions, such as diphenylamine. B. Nitrites in water – The ortho-toluidine test is also not used for measuring nitrites in water. Nitrites can be measured using a variety of other specific tests, including the use of colorimetric reagents for nitrite detection. D. Ammonia content in water – Although ammonia is an important water quality parameter, the ortho-toluidine test does not measure ammonia content. Ammonia is usually measured using methods like the Nessler's reagent test, which involves a different chemical reaction.

questions.text: Most desired temperature range for drinking water is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 10-15°C. 10-15°C – The most desirable temperature range for drinking water is between 10-15°C. This range is generally considered to be ideal for the taste and refreshment qualities of water, providing a comfortable and cool drinking experience without being too cold or too warm. Incorrect Options: A. 0-5°C – While very cold water may seem refreshing, 0-5°C is typically too cold for drinking water, especially for prolonged consumption. Extremely cold water can be uncomfortable to drink and may cause a constriction of blood vessels, which is not ideal for hydration. B. 5-10°C – While this is still a relatively cool temperature, it is not as ideal as 10-15°C, which is the preferred range for most people. At 5-10°C, the water is still quite cool, but not as optimal for regular drinking compared to the slightly warmer 10-15°C. D. 15-20°C – This range is somewhat on the warmer side. While it is still within an acceptable drinking range, water closer to 15-20°C may lose some of the refreshing qualities that cooler water provides, especially in hot weather.

questions.text: Most undesirable metal in drinking water is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lead. Lead – Lead is the most undesirable metal in drinking water. Even small amounts of lead exposure can be highly toxic, especially for young children and pregnant women. It can lead to severe health problems such as developmental delays, neurological damage, and kidney problems. Because of its harmful effects on health, it is strictly regulated and should not be present in drinking water. Incorrect Options: A. Iron – While iron can cause staining and a metallic taste in water, it is generally not as harmful as lead. In large quantities, iron can lead to gastrointestinal issues, but it is not considered as dangerous to health as lead. B. Copper – Copper is another metal that can be found in drinking water, particularly in areas with copper plumbing. Excessive copper levels can lead to nausea, vomiting, and other gastrointestinal issues, but it is typically less toxic than lead. C. Zinc – Zinc is an essential nutrient in small quantities, and its presence in drinking water is not usually harmful in typical concentrations. High concentrations can cause stomach upset, but it is far less hazardous compared to lead.

questions.text: Scabies, an infection of the skin caused by Sarcoptes scabei, is an example of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Water washed disease. Water washed disease – Scabies is classified as a water-washed disease. This means it is spread through close personal contact and by sharing contaminated clothing or bedding. While water does not directly transmit the infection, a lack of access to clean water for washing can increase the likelihood of infection, as poor hygiene and the inability to wash clothing and bedding regularly can facilitate the spread of the mite (Sarcoptes scabei) that causes scabies. Incorrect Options: A. Water borne disease – Waterborne diseases are caused by pathogens (bacteria, viruses, or parasites) that are transmitted through contaminated water. Scabies is not caused by a pathogen in water, so it does not fit into this category. C. Water based disease – Water-based diseases are caused by aquatic organisms (e.g., parasites) that need water to complete their life cycle. Scabies does not fit this category because it is caused by a mite that lives on the skin, not by an organism dependent on water. D. Water related disease – This term typically refers to diseases that are indirectly related to water, such as diseases spread through water contamination affecting food, sanitation, or the environment. Scabies is more specifically classified as a water-washed disease due to its relationship to hygiene and cleanliness.

choices.text: No preliminary storage of raw water is required
Can be gravity types of pressure

questions.text: All are true for rapid sand filters except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Frequent washing is not required. Frequent washing is not required – This statement is incorrect because rapid sand filters require frequent backwashing or cleaning. During the filtration process, the filter media (usually sand) accumulates particles and impurities, which need to be flushed out regularly to maintain the efficiency of the filter. Therefore, frequent washing is indeed required to prevent clogging and to ensure the proper functioning of the filter. Incorrect Options: A. No preliminary storage of raw water is required – This is true. Rapid sand filters can operate without the need for extensive preliminary storage of raw water. In fact, they are designed to handle the flow of water directly through the filtration system, which makes them suitable for continuous filtration in water treatment plants. B. Operation requires highly skilled persons – This is also true. While rapid sand filters are effective, their operation and maintenance do require skilled personnel. Monitoring the filtration process, adjusting flow rates, and managing the backwashing procedure all require technical expertise to ensure the filter is operating efficiently. D. Can be gravity types or pressure – This is true. Rapid sand filters can be designed to operate either under gravity (where water flows through the filter media due to gravitational force) or under pressure (where water is forced through the filter media using a pump). Both designs are commonly used depending on the specific needs of the water treatment system.

questions.text: Disinfecting action of chlorine on water is mainly due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid – Chlorine's disinfecting action in water is primarily due to the formation of hypochlorous acid (HOCl). When chlorine is added to water, it reacts with water to form hypochlorous acid, which is a powerful disinfectant. Hypochlorous acid is highly effective in killing bacteria and viruses by disrupting their cell walls and interfering with their metabolic processes. Incorrect Options: A. Hydrogen chloride – Hydrogen chloride (HCl) is not primarily responsible for the disinfecting action of chlorine in water. While chlorine can produce hydrogen chloride in some reactions, it is not the active disinfectant form in this context. C. Hypochlorite ions – Hypochlorite ions are formed when chlorine reacts with water, but they are less effective than hypochlorous acid in disinfecting. Hypochlorite ions are more stable in basic (alkaline) conditions and less effective as a disinfectant compared to hypochlorous acid, which is more effective in slightly acidic to neutral conditions. D. Hydrogen ions – Hydrogen ions are part of the acidity in the water, but they do not contribute directly to the disinfecting action of chlorine. The disinfecting action is due to the hypochlorous acid formed in the water, not the hydrogen ions themselves.

choices.text: Chlorine Ozone gas and UV radiation

questions.text: Which of the following agents have residual germicidal effect when used for disinfection of water?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chlorine. A. Chlorine – Chlorine is the only agent in the options listed that has a residual germicidal effect when used for disinfection of water. After chlorine is added to water, it continues to act as a disinfectant, maintaining its germicidal properties even after the initial disinfection process. This residual effect helps in preventing any microbial growth that may occur after the water has been treated and is stored or transported. Incorrect Options: B. Chlorine and Ozone gas – Ozone gas is a powerful disinfectant, but it does not have a residual germicidal effect. Ozone rapidly decomposes after disinfection, leaving no long-term residual disinfection capability in the water. C. Chlorine and UV radiation – UV radiation is effective in killing microorganisms by damaging their DNA, but it does not have any residual germicidal effect. Once the UV radiation is turned off, its disinfecting action stops, leaving no ongoing disinfection in the water. D. Chlorine, Ozone gas, and UV radiation – As explained in the previous options, ozone gas and UV radiation both lack residual germicidal effects, so this option is also incorrect.

questions.text: Indicator solution in Horrock’s Apparatus contains
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Starch iodide. Explanation of Correct Response: B. Starch iodide – The indicator solution used in Horrock's Apparatus contains starch iodide. This is commonly used to test for the presence of chlorine in water, as starch iodide reacts with free chlorine, forming a blue color. The change in color indicates the chlorine concentration. Incorrect Options: A. Ortho toulidine – Ortho toulidine is used in some chlorine tests, but it is not the indicator in Horrock's Apparatus. Instead, it is part of other specific tests for determining chlorine concentrations, like the Ortotholuidine test. C. Ortho toulidine arsenite – This is a combination used in other tests for chlorine concentration but not for Horrock's Apparatus. It is used in some colorimetric tests for chlorine determination in water. D. Bromocresol purple – Bromocresol purple is a pH indicator that changes color with changes in pH. It is not used in Horrock’s Apparatus for chlorine detection.

choices.text: 0.5 mg/ L for a contact period of 1hr
0.5 mg/ L for a contact period of ½ hr
1.0 mg/ L for a contact period of 1 hr
1.0 mg/ L for a contract period of ½ hr

questions.text: Minimum recommended dose of free residual chlorine in water for routine chlorination is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 0.5 mg/L for a contact period of 1 hour. A. 0.5 mg/L for a contact period of 1 hour – This is the standard recommendation for the minimum dose of free residual chlorine in drinking water. A chlorine concentration of 0.5 mg/L for a contact period of 1 hour is effective for routine chlorination and ensures that the water is disinfected properly. The contact time is sufficient to allow the chlorine to eliminate most pathogens. Incorrect Options: B. 0.5 mg/L for a contact period of ½ hour – While this dose may still be effective, the standard recommendation usually involves a contact period of 1 hour for better assurance of disinfection. A shorter contact time may not be as reliable in ensuring the effectiveness of disinfection, especially for more resistant microorganisms. C. 1.0 mg/L for a contact period of 1 hour – This higher chlorine concentration might be used in specific situations where there are concerns about higher levels of contamination, but the standard minimum recommended dose for routine chlorination is 0.5 mg/L, not 1.0 mg/L. D. 1.0 mg/L for a contact period of ½ hour – While a higher chlorine concentration can be effective, this combination is not typically recommended as a routine practice. The minimum recommended dose is generally 0.5 mg/L with a longer contact time of 1 hour, ensuring a balance between effective disinfection and economical use of chlorine.

questions.text: What is the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liter of water if 4, 5, 6 cups shows distinct colouration in Horrock’s apparatus:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water can be calculated using the Horrock's apparatus, which typically works by determining the chlorine demand based on the number of cups that show distinct colorations when chlorine is added. In the given scenario, 4, 5, and 6 cups show distinct colorations. This suggests a specific chlorine dose that needs to be added to the water to achieve the desired disinfection level. The exact amount of chlorine required depends on the chlorine demand (which is determined using the Horrock’s apparatus). Bleaching powder contains around 35% chlorine. Based on this, if the correct amount of bleaching powder is 8 grams for the required chlorine demand, it matches the solution provided. Incorrect Options: A. 2 g – This is too little for the volume of water (455 liters) and the number of colorations in the Horrock's apparatus. A small amount of chlorine will not be sufficient to meet the disinfection requirements. B. 6 g – This amount may provide some chlorine but would not be adequate for a proper and complete disinfection of 455 liters, as more chlorine would be needed. D. 4 g – This is also insufficient based on the Horrock’s apparatus readings and the volume of water being treated.

questions.text: In a slow filter, the element responsible for yielding bacteria free water is the:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In a slow sand filter, the vital layer is the key component responsible for yielding bacteria-free water. This vital layer, often referred to as the "schmutzdecke," is a thin layer of biological material that forms on the top of the sand filter. It plays a crucial role in removing bacteria, viruses, and other microorganisms through both physical filtration and biological processes such as predation by microorganisms. Incorrect Options: A. Valve – The valve controls the flow of water but is not involved in the filtration process that removes bacteria. C. Supernatant water – This is the clear water that lies above the sand filter bed, but it is not directly responsible for bacterial removal. It is the filtered water that has passed through the vital layer and the sand. D. Under-drainage system – The under-drainage system helps in collecting the filtered water from the bottom of the filter bed but does not participate in removing bacteria.

questions.text: Nalgonda technique for defluroridation is what sequence:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lime then Alum. The Nalgonda technique for defluoridation involves the addition of lime (calcium hydroxide) followed by alum (aluminum sulfate). Lime is used to raise the pH of the water, which helps in precipitating fluoride as calcium fluoride. Alum is then added to further aid in coagulation and flocculation, removing the precipitated fluoride along with other impurities. This sequence ensures that fluoride is effectively removed from the water. Incorrect Options: B. Soda then Alum – Soda (sodium bicarbonate) is not typically used in the Nalgonda technique for fluoride removal. While soda can influence pH, it is not part of the standard defluoridation process as it does not effectively precipitate fluoride. C. Alum then Soda – In this sequence, the order is incorrect. Alum is supposed to follow lime for effective fluoride removal, not soda. Soda is not a key component in the Nalgonda technique. D. Alum then Lime – This is the reverse of the correct sequence. Lime must be added first to raise the pH before alum is added for coagulation, as lime helps in the initial precipitation of fluoride.

questions.text: Confirmatory Test for coliform count:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Eijkman test. The Eijkman test is a confirmatory test used to detect the presence of coliforms in water. It involves inoculating a water sample into a medium and observing for gas production, which is a characteristic of coliform bacteria. This test helps confirm the presence of coliforms and thus indicates the potential contamination of water. Incorrect Options: B. Casoni’s test – This test is not related to coliform detection. It is used to diagnose echinococcosis (hydatid disease) by detecting hydatid cyst antigens, not for coliforms. C. Nitrate test – This test detects the presence of nitrates, which can be found in water as a result of agricultural runoff or contamination from sewage, but it is not used to confirm coliform presence. D. Urease test – This test is used to detect organisms that produce urease, an enzyme that breaks down urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide. While some bacteria produce urease, it is not used to specifically confirm coliforms.

questions.text: Test for recent contamination of water is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Nitrites. Nitrites are a more specific indicator of recent contamination of water, especially from sewage or agricultural runoff. When nitrates are reduced under anaerobic conditions, they are converted to nitrites. A high concentration of nitrites in water suggests recent contamination, as nitrates typically accumulate more slowly and indicate longer-term contamination. Incorrect Options: A. Nitrates – Nitrates are commonly found in water due to agricultural runoff or pollution, but they do not specifically indicate recent contamination. Nitrates are more stable in water, so while their presence can signal contamination, they don't provide the immediacy that nitrites do. C. Ammonia – While ammonia can be an indicator of pollution, it is less specific for recent contamination compared to nitrites. Ammonia levels can persist in water for longer periods, so it is not as immediate a sign of fresh contamination. D. Chlorides – Chlorides in water are a sign of general pollution but are not a reliable marker for recent contamination. They are naturally present in water and can also come from seawater, industrial waste, and other sources unrelated to recent sewage contamination.

questions.text: Fresh bleaching powder contains:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 33% chlorine. Fresh bleaching powder, which is primarily calcium hypochlorite, contains around 33% available chlorine by weight. This chlorine is responsible for its disinfecting properties, as it reacts with water to release chlorine, which is a powerful disinfectant. Incorrect Options: B. 3.3% chlorine – This is incorrect because fresh bleaching powder has a higher percentage of chlorine content than this. A concentration of 3.3% chlorine would be too low for effective disinfection. C. 0.33% chlorine – This is also incorrect. This percentage is much too low for fresh bleaching powder, which has a much higher chlorine content to ensure its disinfecting effectiveness. D. 0.033% chlorine – This percentage is far too low to be applicable to fresh bleaching powder. This level of chlorine would not be effective for disinfection, as it would require a much higher concentration.

questions.text: All the following assess the waterquality-criteria for water pollution are all Except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Solid particles. Solid particles are not typically used to assess water quality in terms of water pollution criteria. Water quality is generally evaluated by measuring parameters that affect the chemical, biological, and physical characteristics of the water, such as dissolved oxygen, chlorides, and nitrogen content. Solid particles, although they may be present in polluted water, are not standard criteria for assessing water quality. Instead, they may be quantified through turbidity tests or suspended solids measurements, which are indirect indicators, not direct quality criteria like those listed in the other options. Incorrect Options: B. Dissolved oxygen – Dissolved oxygen (DO) is a key criterion in assessing water quality. It is essential for the survival of aquatic organisms, and its concentration is a direct indicator of water pollution. Low levels of dissolved oxygen suggest that the water may be polluted with organic matter, leading to oxygen consumption by bacteria. C. Dissolved chloride – Dissolved chloride is an important parameter for assessing water quality. High chloride levels can indicate contamination from various sources, including industrial discharges, sewage, or salinity intrusion. Elevated chloride levels are often associated with pollution. D. Dissolved nitrogen – Dissolved nitrogen compounds, such as nitrate and nitrite, are commonly used to assess water quality. These compounds can come from agricultural runoff, wastewater discharge, or industrial pollution. Excessive nitrogen levels can lead to eutrophication and water quality degradation.

questions.text: Effective size of sand in rapid sand filter is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 0.5 mm. In a rapid sand filter, the effective size of the sand typically ranges around 0.5 mm. This size is optimal for the filtration process as it allows the sand to effectively remove particles while maintaining a good flow rate. The effective size is crucial in determining the filter's performance in trapping particles and providing clean water. Incorrect Options: A. 0.2 mm – While smaller sand particles can be used in filtration, a 0.2 mm size is too fine for a rapid sand filter. It would result in high pressure loss and reduced efficiency due to clogging, making it unsuitable for the rapid filtration process. C. 0.8 mm – Larger sand particles, like 0.8 mm, might cause the filter to be less effective in trapping fine particles, and they also tend to reduce the filtration speed as the water passes through. D. 0.1 mm – A 0.1 mm sand size is too fine and could lead to problems such as clogging and excessive resistance to water flow. Fine particles could block the filter too quickly, reducing the filter's efficiency and requiring more frequent maintenance.

questions.text: When river water is stored for the first 5-7 days, the bacterial count drops by as much as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 90%. When river water is stored for the first 5-7 days, a significant reduction in the bacterial count occurs, with studies showing that the bacterial population can drop by as much as 90%. This decrease happens due to the natural settling and die-off of microorganisms in the stored water, which helps improve the water quality for further treatment. Incorrect Options: A. 25% – A 25% reduction is too small compared to the substantial decline typically seen in the first 5-7 days of storage. The reduction in bacterial count is much higher due to the natural processes occurring in the water during this period. B. 50% – While some reduction in bacterial count occurs, 50% is still too low when compared to the typical 90?crease observed in the first 5-7 days of storage. The period is long enough for more significant bacterial reduction to occur. D. 100% – A complete elimination of bacteria (100% drop) is unlikely in this short time frame. Some bacteria may still persist even after 5-7 days of storage, although their numbers are significantly reduced.

questions.text: Drawback of ozone as water disinfectant is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) No residual action. One of the main drawbacks of ozone as a water disinfectant is that it does not have any residual disinfection effect. This means that once ozone is used to treat the water, it decomposes quickly, leaving no lasting germicidal effect in the water. This lack of residual action means that the treated water may be susceptible to re-contamination after the treatment process. Incorrect Options: A. No virucidal effect – This is incorrect. Ozone actually has virucidal properties and is effective in inactivating many viruses in water. It is known for its broad-spectrum disinfectant capabilities, including its ability to kill viruses. B. Long time period for action – This is also incorrect. Ozone acts quickly in disinfecting water, typically within a short time frame (minutes). It is a fast-acting disinfectant compared to some other chemicals. C. Teratogenicity – There is no significant evidence to suggest that ozone is teratogenic (causing birth defects). Ozone is harmful at high concentrations, but its use in water treatment, when applied properly, does not pose teratogenic risks.

choices.text: Where no water source in a distance of 1.6 km from community
Water is more than depth of 15 meter
There is excess of Na+, K+, F+ salts

questions.text: Criteria for “Problem village” include all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) BOD slightly de-ranged. BOD slightly de-ranged is incorrect because Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD) is a measure of organic pollution in water, and a "problem village" is not typically classified based on slightly elevated BOD levels. BOD being slightly de-ranged doesn't necessarily indicate a critical water quality issue that would make a village a "problem village." The focus is usually on more severe issues such as water scarcity or contamination. Incorrect Options: A. Where no water source in a distance of 1.6 km from community – This is a valid criterion for a "problem village." If a village does not have a water source within a reasonable distance (like 1.6 km), it indicates that the community is facing water scarcity, which qualifies it as a problem village. B. Water is more than depth of 15 meters – This is another valid criterion. If the water table is deeper than 15 meters, it suggests that accessing water is difficult and may indicate water scarcity or problematic water accessibility, which could qualify a village as a "problem village." C. There is excess of Na+, K+, F+ salts – Excessive salts, including sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), or fluoride (F+), can make water unsafe for consumption and are a key indicator of water quality problems in a village, making it eligible to be categorized as a "problem village."

questions.text: Psychrometer is used to measure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Humidity. A. Humidity – A psychrometer is specifically designed to measure the relative humidity of the air. It consists of two thermometers, a dry bulb thermometer and a wet bulb thermometer, and the difference in their readings is used to calculate the relative humidity. This makes it an essential tool for measuring humidity levels in the atmosphere. Explanation for incorrect answers: B. Air velocity – Psychrometers are not used to measure air velocity. Air velocity is typically measured using an anemometer, which is a different instrument designed to measure the speed of airflow. C. Room temperature – While the psychrometer uses thermometers to measure temperature (specifically the dry bulb temperature), its primary purpose is to measure humidity, not just room temperature. A regular thermometer would be used to measure room temperature. D. Radiant heat – A psychrometer does not measure radiant heat. Radiant heat is typically measured using instruments like a radiometer or pyrometer, which are designed to detect heat radiation.

questions.text: All are indicators of air pollution except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mc Ardle’s index. B. Mc Ardle’s index – Mc Ardle’s index is not an indicator of air pollution. It is actually a measure used in the context of dietary studies or metabolic rate assessments, and is not related to air quality or pollution levels. Therefore, this is the correct option as it does not pertain to air pollution. Incorrect answers: A. Soiling index – The soiling index measures the extent of dust and dirt accumulated on surfaces as a result of air pollution. It is a useful indicator of particulate matter in the air and helps assess the pollution levels in urban environments. C. Suspended particle count – Suspended particulate matter (SPM) or suspended particle count is a direct indicator of air pollution. It refers to the concentration of fine particles like dust, soot, and other pollutants suspended in the air, which can have significant health impacts. D. SO2 Concentration – The concentration of sulfur dioxide (SO2) in the air is a key indicator of air pollution. SO2 is a harmful gas produced by burning fossil fuels, and its presence in the air is closely monitored to assess air quality and potential health risks.

questions.text: Mc Ardle’s maximum allowable sweat rate is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 4.5 lit/ 4 hours. 4.5 lit/ 4 hours – Mc Ardle’s maximum allowable sweat rate refers to the highest rate at which the body can safely sweat without causing dehydration or heat-related issues. According to Mc Ardle's guidelines, the maximum sweat rate is 4.5 liters per 4 hours, which is considered the upper limit of safe fluid loss through sweating during physical activity or exposure to high heat. Incorrect Options: A. 1 lit/ 4 hours – This is below the typical maximum allowable sweat rate according to Mc Ardle’s guidelines, as the body can typically sweat more than 1 liter over 4 hours during exercise or high heat exposure. B. 4 lit/ 1 hour – This rate is quite high and would likely lead to significant dehydration. It is much higher than what Mc Ardle’s guidelines suggest as the maximum safe sweat rate. D. 4.5 lit/ 8 hours – While 4.5 liters over 8 hours might still be manageable in certain conditions, it would generally be considered less than the allowable maximum rate compared to 4.5 liters over 4 hours, which is the established limit.

choices.text: Air temperature, humidity and air movement

questions.text: Kata thermometer measures:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Air temperature, humidity, and air movement. Air temperature, humidity, and air movement – The Kata thermometer is an instrument designed to measure not only the air temperature and humidity but also the air movement (or air velocity). It is typically used in environmental and occupational health settings to assess the overall conditions of an area in terms of thermal comfort and ventilation. Incorrect Options: A. Air temperature only – This is incorrect because the Kata thermometer does more than measure just air temperature. It is specifically designed to assess multiple environmental factors, not just one. B. Air temperature and humidity – While the Kata thermometer does measure both air temperature and humidity, it also measures air movement, which makes this answer incomplete. D. Air velocity only – This is also incorrect because the Kata thermometer measures not just air velocity but a combination of factors, including air temperature and humidity, in addition to air movement.

questions.text: ‘Cooling Power’ of air is measured by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Kata thermometer. Kata thermometer – The Kata thermometer is specifically designed to measure the cooling power of air. It does this by assessing not just the air temperature and humidity but also air movement, which together determine the cooling effect or comfort level of the environment, especially in terms of heat stress and thermal comfort. Incorrect Options: B. Hygrometer – A hygrometer is used to measure humidity levels in the air, but it does not measure the cooling power of air. It is focused on just one aspect of the environment, so it cannot provide the full picture of cooling power. C. Anemometer – An anemometer is used to measure the velocity of the wind or air movement. While air movement is part of cooling power, it doesn't measure the combined effect of air temperature and humidity, which are also essential for determining cooling power. D. Sling’s Psychrometer – A Sling’s Psychrometer measures the relative humidity of the air, but it does not directly measure the cooling power. While it helps estimate moisture in the air, it is not designed to measure the combined effect of temperature, humidity, and air movement.

questions.text: The mean radiant temperature is measured by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Globe thermometer. Globe thermometer – The globe thermometer is specifically designed to measure the mean radiant temperature (MRT), which is a measure of the average temperature of all surrounding surfaces that radiate heat to the person. It is a blackened sphere with a thermometer placed inside to measure the temperature of the air and surfaces that surround it. This is crucial in understanding the heat environment and human comfort. Incorrect Options: A. Dry bulb thermometer – The dry bulb thermometer measures the ambient air temperature. However, it does not account for radiant heat, which is essential for measuring the mean radiant temperature. It only gives the air temperature, which is not sufficient for evaluating the total thermal environment. B. Wet bulb thermometer – The wet bulb thermometer measures the humidity in the air by using the principle of evaporative cooling. While it provides useful information about humidity, it does not directly measure radiant heat or the mean radiant temperature. C. Six’s maximum and minimum thermometer – The Six's maximum and minimum thermometer is used to record the highest and lowest air temperatures in a given period. It does not measure the mean radiant temperature, which is specifically concerned with the radiant heat from surrounding surfaces.

choices.text: Kyoto protocol called for 20% reduction in greenhouse emissions

questions.text: Global warming true is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CO2 is a major greenhouse gas A. CO2 is a major greenhouse gas – Carbon dioxide (CO2) is indeed one of the primary greenhouse gases contributing to global warming. It traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere, leading to an increase in the Earth's average temperature. This is a major driver of climate change, as increasing levels of CO2 from human activities like burning fossil fuels lead to a warming effect. Incorrect Options: B. Stratosphere ozone layer is harmful – The ozone layer in the stratosphere actually plays a crucial role in protecting life on Earth by absorbing most of the sun's harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation. It is not harmful; rather, its depletion, caused by chemicals like CFCs, is a concern for human health and the environment. C. CFC increases stratosphere ozone layer – Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) are actually harmful to the ozone layer. They contribute to its depletion by breaking down ozone molecules in the stratosphere. This results in the thinning of the ozone layer, which allows more harmful UV radiation to reach the Earth. D. Kyoto protocol called for 20% reduction in greenhouse emissions – The Kyoto Protocol, adopted in 1997, aimed for developed countries to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions by an average of 5.2% from 1990 levels by 2012, not 20%. The protocol set specific targets for each country, and while it did not mandate a uniform 20% reduction, it encouraged action on a global scale to combat climate change.

questions.text: The best parameter to measure air pollution is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) SO2 (Sulfur Dioxide) A. SO2 (Sulfur Dioxide) – Sulfur dioxide is considered one of the best parameters to measure air pollution because it is a major pollutant released from burning fossil fuels, particularly coal and oil, in power plants and industrial processes. SO2 is a harmful gas that can lead to the formation of acid rain, respiratory issues, and environmental damage. Monitoring SO2 levels helps in assessing air quality and the potential for air pollution-related health risks. Incorrect Options: B. CO2 (Carbon Dioxide) – While carbon dioxide is a significant greenhouse gas contributing to climate change, it is not typically used as a direct measure of air pollution. CO2 is more related to global warming than to traditional air quality concerns such as smog or respiratory pollutants. C. CO (Carbon Monoxide) – Carbon monoxide is a harmful gas produced by incomplete combustion, and it can be used to measure air pollution in certain contexts, especially in urban environments where traffic is a major source. However, SO2 is more commonly used as a direct indicator of overall air pollution due to its direct link to industrial activities and its environmental impacts. D. N2O (Nitrous Oxide) – Nitrous oxide is a potent greenhouse gas but is not typically used to measure air pollution. It is more relevant to climate change studies than to conventional air quality monitoring.

questions.text: Acceptable level for physical comfort:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Corrected effective temperature 77-80°F Corrected effective temperature 77-80°F – The corrected effective temperature (CET) is a measure used to assess thermal comfort, accounting for factors like air temperature, humidity, and air movement. A CET range of 77-80°F is generally considered comfortable for most people in typical indoor environments. This range strikes a balance between preventing heat stress and ensuring comfort in various conditions. Incorrect Options: B. Corrected effective temperature 70-76°F – This temperature range is on the lower side and may be comfortable for some, but it can be too cool for others, depending on humidity and air movement. It falls outside the typical comfort range for many people. C. Corrected effective temperature 80-81°F – While this range may be acceptable for some people, it may be too warm for comfort for many individuals, especially in areas with high humidity or inadequate air circulation. D. Corrected effective temperature >82°F – This range is generally considered too warm for comfort and could lead to discomfort or heat stress for most people in indoor environments. It is above the typical comfort zone.

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

questions.text: Which agency monitors air quality in India?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Central Pollution Control Board Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) – The CPCB is the statutory body under the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change, Government of India. It is responsible for monitoring and regulating air quality across the country. The CPCB sets air quality standards, conducts research, and publishes data related to air pollution, helping to ensure that air quality is maintained within acceptable limits. Incorrect Options: A. Central Research Institute – While research institutes may engage in environmental studies, the CPCB specifically monitors air quality and enforces regulations regarding air pollution. The Central Research Institute is not directly involved in air quality monitoring. B. Ministry of Health and Family Welfare – This ministry is responsible for public health policies and initiatives in India, but it is not directly responsible for air quality monitoring. However, air quality can influence public health, which is a concern of the Ministry of Health. C. National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI) – NEERI is an important research body involved in environmental engineering, including air pollution studies, but it is not the main regulatory body for monitoring air quality. The CPCB is the body responsible for the regulatory monitoring of air quality in India.

questions.text: In winter, water vapours and pollutants comes to lie in the lowermost layer atmosphere by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Temperature inversion Temperature inversion – In winter, temperature inversion occurs when a layer of warmer air traps cooler air near the ground. This causes water vapour and pollutants to accumulate in the lower atmosphere instead of rising and dispersing. The trapped pollutants can lead to a significant increase in air pollution levels near the surface. This phenomenon is particularly common in urban areas during cold weather, leading to smog and poor air quality. Incorrect Options: A. Acid rain – Acid rain is the result of air pollutants, such as sulfur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxides (NOx), reacting with water vapour in the atmosphere to form sulfuric and nitric acids. While acid rain is a serious environmental issue, it does not directly explain the trapping of water vapours and pollutants in the lower atmosphere in winter. B. Greenhouse effect – The greenhouse effect refers to the trapping of heat in the Earth's atmosphere due to greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, methane, and water vapour. While this contributes to global warming, it does not specifically explain the situation where water vapours and pollutants accumulate near the ground in winter. D. Ocean effect – The ocean effect involves the impact of ocean currents and water temperature on weather patterns. While the ocean can influence local climates, it does not directly cause the phenomenon where pollutants are trapped in the lower atmosphere during winter.

questions.text: At which level of heat stress index it is not possible to work comfortably causing thereat to health:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 40-60 40-60 – A Heat Stress Index (HSI) in the range of 40-60 indicates a moderate to high level of heat stress, which can make working uncomfortable and pose a threat to health. At this level, individuals may experience signs of heat exhaustion, dehydration, and heat-related illnesses. Prolonged exposure to these conditions can result in a serious health threat, such as heat stroke, especially in workers who are exerting themselves physically in hot environments. It is generally recommended that additional measures, such as hydration and rest breaks, be provided to prevent health complications. Incorrect Options: A. 20-40 – This range typically represents a moderate heat stress index, where working conditions may be uncomfortable, but the risk to health is generally low if proper precautions are taken (such as hydration and appropriate clothing). People can still work relatively comfortably at this level without significant health risks. C. 60-80 – Although the heat stress increases significantly at this level, it is still manageable with additional safety measures such as cool rest areas and more frequent hydration. However, if precautions are not followed, health risks such as heat exhaustion and dehydration can increase. D. 80-100 – At this level, heat stress is extreme, and prolonged exposure without rest or cooling measures can lead to severe health risks like heat stroke. However, this option is not the best answer to the specific question since 40-60 is already a threshold where health risks start to become significant without proper care, while 80-100 would be even more dangerous.

questions.text: Number of air changes in a drawing room per hour should be at least:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 2-3 2-3 – The recommended number of air changes in a drawing room per hour is 2-3. This level of ventilation ensures that the air quality is maintained and that there is adequate exchange of indoor and outdoor air, helping to remove excess moisture, pollutants, and odors. It also helps in maintaining a comfortable atmosphere in the room. This amount of ventilation is typically sufficient for residential spaces such as living or drawing rooms, where comfort and air quality are key. Incorrect Options: B. 3-4 – While 3-4 air changes per hour might be appropriate for spaces with higher occupancy or specialized ventilation needs, it’s typically not necessary for a standard drawing room. The standard recommendation of 2-3 air changes is usually sufficient for residential spaces without making the room feel overly drafty or uncomfortable. C. 4-5 – This level of air changes may be required in areas with a higher concentration of pollutants, such as kitchens or laboratories, but it is generally excessive for a typical drawing room. More frequent air changes might lead to unnecessary energy consumption and discomfort in a home setting. D. 5-6 – This range is typically seen in spaces where very high ventilation rates are needed, like in certain industrial or commercial spaces, or areas with high occupancy and specific ventilation needs. It's not required for a drawing room unless specific circumstances dictate otherwise.

questions.text: In indoor air pollution, carbon monoxide is produced by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Carbon monoxide is produced in case of incomplete combustion or in places where the levels of oxygen is less

questions.text: CO2 in air measured by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Kiffer test Kiffer test – The Kiffer test is a method used to measure the concentration of carbon dioxide in the air. This test involves a chemical reaction that allows for the quantification of CO2 levels. It is a commonly used technique for detecting and measuring CO2 in both indoor and outdoor environments, as it is reliable for determining air quality in spaces where CO2 levels need to be monitored. Incorrect Options: A. Manometer – A manometer is a device used to measure pressure, not the concentration of gases like CO2. It can measure the pressure of gases, but not the specific concentration of carbon dioxide in the air. B. Hygrometer – A hygrometer measures the humidity or moisture content in the air, not the concentration of carbon dioxide. It does not provide any information about CO2 levels. D. None – This option is incorrect because the Kiffer test is indeed a method used for measuring CO2 concentration in the air. Therefore, there is a correct option among the choices.

questions.text: Whispering produces a sound of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 20-30 dB 20-30 dB – Whispering typically produces sound levels in the range of 20-30 decibels (dB). This is a very soft sound, below normal conversational levels, which usually range from 60 to 70 dB. Whispering is quiet and barely audible from a distance, hence the lower dB range. Incorrect Options: B. 30-40 dB – While this range may apply to soft speaking voices, it is slightly higher than the sound produced by whispering. A sound at 30-40 dB is still soft, but not as faint as a whisper. C. 40-50 dB – This range corresponds to a normal speaking voice at a moderate volume. It is louder than a whisper and more typical of regular conversation or background noise. D. 50-60 dB – This range is typical for conversational speech at a normal volume, or for everyday sounds like a normal office environment. It is significantly louder than a whisper.

questions.text: The minimum floor space recommended per adult person in a dwelling place is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 50-100 sq ft. A. 50-100 sq ft – The minimum floor space recommended for an adult person in a dwelling place typically falls within the 50-100 square feet range. This is considered an adequate space for basic living conditions, allowing enough room for personal movement and minimal essential furniture. Incorrect Options: B. 101-450 sq ft – This range represents more comfortable living spaces for one person, providing additional room for more furniture, storage, and movement. While it offers more space than the minimum required, it is not the minimum standard. C. 151-200 sq ft – A dwelling space within this range would be considered quite spacious for an individual, offering ample room for various activities. This exceeds the minimum requirement. D. 201-250 sq ft – This size is far above the minimum recommended floor space for a single adult, reflecting much larger living areas typically seen in more comfortable and spacious living environments.

choices.text: Size of suspended particles in the air
Bed resistance in a low sand filter

questions.text: Venturimeter is used to measure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bed resistance in a low sand filter Bed resistance in a low sand filter – A venturimeter is an instrument primarily used to measure the flow rate of liquids or gases by observing the change in pressure as the fluid passes through a constricted section. In the context of a low sand filter, a venturimeter is useful in measuring the bed resistance, which refers to the resistance the water faces while passing through the filter media (sand). This helps in assessing the filter’s performance. Incorrect Options: A. Air velocity – Air velocity is typically measured by an anemometer, not a venturimeter. A venturimeter measures pressure changes due to flow, not air velocity directly. B. Size of suspended particles in the air – The size of suspended particles in the air is usually measured using a particle size analyzer or similar devices, not a venturimeter. C. SO2 content in the atmosphere – The SO2 content is typically measured using specialized gas analyzers, such as a sulfur dioxide analyzer, not a venturimeter.

questions.text: Soiling index is a measure of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Air pollution Air pollution – The soiling index is a measure used to assess the effect of air pollution on surfaces, particularly how airborne pollutants such as soot, dust, and particulate matter can cause staining or soiling of buildings, monuments, and other surfaces. It indicates the level of air pollution based on the accumulation of dirt or soot on exposed surfaces. Hence, it is directly related to air pollution. Incorrect Options: A. Soil pollution – The soiling index does not measure soil pollution. Soil pollution typically involves the contamination of soil with harmful substances such as chemicals, heavy metals, or pesticides, which is a different area of concern. B. Water pollution – The soiling index is not used for assessing water pollution. Water pollution involves the contamination of water bodies, typically measured by factors like chemical contaminants, microbial load, and suspended solids, which is distinct from the concept of soiling in air. C. Noise pollution – Soiling index is not related to noise pollution. Noise pollution refers to harmful or disruptive sounds in the environment, and is typically measured using sound level meters or similar equipment, not by the soiling of surfaces.

questions.text: Mites are the vectors of the following disease except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Kyasanur forest disease Kyasanur forest disease – Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) is a viral infection transmitted by ticks, not mites. The disease is primarily found in parts of India and is transmitted through the bite of infected ticks, specifically the Haemaphysalis species. Mites are not involved in the transmission of KFD. Incorrect Options: A. Scabies – Scabies is caused by the Sarcoptes scabiei mite, which burrows into the skin, leading to intense itching and skin rashes. It is one of the diseases transmitted by mites. B. Scrub typhus – Scrub typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi, and it is transmitted by mites, specifically the chigger mites. Mites are the vectors responsible for spreading the bacteria to humans. C. Rickettsial pox – Rickettsial pox is caused by the bacterium Rickettsia akari and is transmitted by mites, particularly the house mouse mite. This disease is also associated with mite vectors.

questions.text: Pyrethrum is a:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Contact poison Contact poison – Pyrethrum is a natural insecticide derived from the flowers of certain chrysanthemums. It works as a contact poison, meaning it kills insects when they come into direct contact with it. Pyrethrum affects the nervous system of insects, leading to paralysis and death. It does not need to be ingested by the insect, but rather it is effective when applied directly to their bodies. Incorrect Options: B. Stomach poison – A stomach poison works by being ingested by the insect, and the poison affects the insect's digestive system. Pyrethrum is not a stomach poison, as it kills by contact, not ingestion. C. Both a + b – Since pyrethrum is specifically a contact poison and not a stomach poison, this option is incorrect. D. Space poison – A space poison refers to a substance that is effective in the air or environment around the insect, such as a fumigant. Pyrethrum is not a space poison, as it requires direct contact with the insect's body to be effective.

questions.text: Mosquitoes that breed in dirty water collection are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Culex Culex – Culex mosquitoes are known to breed in dirty water or stagnant water that is contaminated with organic matter. They are commonly found in areas like cesspools, ditches, and containers with poor drainage, where water tends to collect and stagnate. Culex mosquitoes are vectors for diseases like West Nile virus, Japanese encephalitis, and filariasis. Incorrect Options: A. Anopheles – Anopheles mosquitoes breed in clean, unpolluted water, typically in ponds, lakes, or marshes. They are the primary vectors of malaria, but their breeding sites are usually not dirty water collections. C. Aedes – Aedes mosquitoes are commonly found breeding in clean, stagnant water sources, such as containers, discarded tires, and water stored in household items, but not typically in dirty water. They are vectors for diseases like dengue, Zika, and chikungunya. D. Mansonia – Mansonia mosquitoes also breed in aquatic plants in clean water, especially in marshy or swampy areas. They do not primarily breed in dirty water collections, and are known to transmit diseases like lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: Example of cyclopropagative transmission is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Malarial parasite in mosquito Malarial parasite in mosquito – Cyclopropagative transmission refers to a type of transmission where both the development and multiplication of the pathogen occur within the vector. In the case of malaria, the Plasmodium parasite undergoes both developmental stages (sporogony) and multiplication within the mosquito (Anopheles), thus making it an example of cyclopropagative transmission. Incorrect Options: A. Plague bacilli in the flea – This is an example of propagative transmission, where the plague bacilli multiply within the flea, but there is no developmental stage of the pathogen in the flea. The pathogen does not undergo changes in the flea, unlike in cyclopropagative transmission. C. Microfilaria in mosquito – This involves propagative transmission, as the microfilaria undergoes development within the mosquito, but it does not multiply within the mosquito. The parasite remains in its initial form, undergoing development, but not multiple stages of reproduction. D. Guinea worm embryo in Cyclops – This is an example of direct transmission or developmental transmission, where the embryo develops inside the Cyclops, but there is no multiplication of the pathogen. It doesn't fit the definition of cyclopropagative transmission, as it lacks both development and multiplication within the vector.

choices.text: Agent changes in form and number: cyclo propagative transmission
Agent merely multiplies in vector but no developmental form change multiplication: cyclo developmental transmission
Agent undergoes only development but no multiplication: cyclo developmental transmission
Agent transmitted from nymph to adult vector: Transovarial transmission

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Agent merely multiplies in vector but no developmental form change multiplication: cyclo developmental transmission Agent merely multiplies in vector but no developmental form change multiplication: cyclo developmental transmission – This is incorrectly matched. Cyclo developmental transmission refers to a scenario where the agent undergoes both development and multiplication within the vector. The statement here, which indicates no developmental form change, does not fit the definition of cyclo developmental transmission. Instead, this matches a propagative transmission, where the agent multiplies but doesn't undergo development in the vector. Incorrect Options: A. Agent changes in form and number: cyclo propagative transmission – This is correctly matched. Cyclo propagative transmission involves the agent undergoing both development (change in form) and multiplication (change in number) in the vector. An example of this would be the malaria parasite in mosquitoes. C. Agent undergoes only development but no multiplication: cyclo developmental transmission – This is correctly matched. Cyclo developmental transmission occurs when the pathogen undergoes development (change in form) within the vector but does not multiply (no increase in number). An example is the filarial worms in mosquitoes. D. Agent transmitted from nymph to adult vector: Transovarial transmission – This is correctly matched. Transovarial transmission occurs when the pathogen is transmitted from the female vector to its offspring (from the nymph to the adult). An example is the plague bacterium in fleas.

choices.text: It is a definitive host in malaria
It is a definitive host in filarial
Its life cycle is completed in 3 weeks
Female can travel up to 3 kilometer

questions.text: All of the following statement about mosquito are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It is a definitive host in filarial It is a definitive host in filarial – This is incorrect. A mosquito is not the definitive host for filarial worms. In the case of filarial infections, such as those caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, the mosquito acts as an intermediate host. The definitive host for filarial worms is usually a human, where the adult worms live and mature. Mosquitoes serve to transmit the larvae of the filarial worms to humans but do not serve as the final host for the adult parasites. Incorrect Options: A. It is a definitive host in malaria – This is correct. In the case of malaria, the mosquito is the definitive host for the Plasmodium parasite. The parasite undergoes its sexual reproduction in the mosquito, which is why the mosquito is considered the definitive host. C. Its life cycle is completed in 3 weeks – This is correct. The life cycle of a mosquito, from egg to adult, typically takes about 3 weeks, depending on environmental conditions like temperature and availability of water. D. Female can travel up to 3 kilometers – This is correct. Female mosquitoes, especially those of the Aedes and Anopheles species, can fly long distances and are known to travel up to 3 kilometers in search of a blood meal.

questions.text: Which of the following flies do not bite?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Housefly Housefly – This is correct. The housefly (Musca domestica) does not bite humans. Houseflies are non-biting flies that feed on liquids and decaying matter. They do not have specialized mouthparts for biting or piercing skin. Instead, they feed by landing on food or surfaces and regurgitating saliva, which contains digestive enzymes to liquefy food. Incorrect Options: A. Sand fly – This is incorrect. Sand flies are biting flies. They are known for transmitting diseases like leishmaniasis and sandfly fever. The females bite to feed on blood, which is necessary for egg production. C. Blackfly – This is incorrect. Blackflies are also biting flies. They bite humans and animals to feed on blood, and they are known to transmit diseases such as onchocerciasis (river blindness) in some regions. D. Tse tse fly – This is incorrect. Tsetse flies are biting flies as well. They are responsible for transmitting trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) in humans and animals. The female tsetse fly feeds on blood to support egg development.

questions.text: Which of the following files is found in cracks and crevices of walls during daytime?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sand fly Sand fly – This is correct. Sand flies are typically found in cracks and crevices of walls during the daytime. They are nocturnal creatures, meaning they are more active at night when they feed on the blood of humans and animals. During the daytime, they tend to hide in cool, dark places like cracks and crevices in walls, under rocks, or in animal burrows to avoid the heat and sunlight. Incorrect Options: B. House fly – This is incorrect. Houseflies are usually found in open, accessible places such as food surfaces or garbage. They do not typically hide in cracks and crevices during the daytime. Instead, they are active throughout the day and are commonly seen on food, waste, or other surfaces where they can feed. C. Blackfly – This is incorrect. Blackflies are commonly found near water sources where they breed, like rivers or streams. They are more active during the day, but they do not typically hide in cracks and crevices in walls. Their larvae are aquatic, and they are not known for hiding in such places during the day. D. Tse tse fly – This is incorrect. Tsetse flies are typically found in forested or bush areas in sub-Saharan Africa, where they feed on the blood of humans and animals. They are most active during the day, and they tend to rest in the shade, but they do not specifically hide in cracks and crevices in walls.

questions.text: All of the following disease are caused by Soft Tick except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tularemia Tularemia – This is correct. Tularemia is caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis and is typically transmitted by hard ticks (Ixodidae), not soft ticks. The disease is commonly associated with tick bites, handling infected animals, or exposure to contaminated water. Soft ticks do not play a significant role in transmitting Tularemia. Incorrect Options: B. Q fever – This is incorrect. Q fever is caused by the bacterium Coxiella burnetii, which is primarily transmitted by soft ticks (family Argasidae). Soft ticks are the main vectors for this disease, especially in rural areas with livestock. C. Relapsing fever – This is incorrect. Relapsing fever is caused by various species of Borrelia bacteria and is transmitted by soft ticks (Argasidae). These ticks are the primary vectors for the tick-borne relapsing fever. D. KFD (Kyasanur Forest Disease) – This is incorrect. Kyasanur Forest Disease is a tick-borne viral disease transmitted by hard ticks (Ixodidae), specifically Haemaphysalis species. It does not involve soft ticks in its transmission cycle.

questions.text: Most cost effective approach to control of arthropods is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Environmental control Environmental control – This is correct. Environmental control is the most cost-effective approach to controlling arthropods because it involves modifying the environment to make it less hospitable to pests. This can include measures such as eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed, improving sanitation to prevent pests from thriving, and creating physical barriers like screens to reduce insect entry. These methods are relatively inexpensive and sustainable, with long-term benefits that can significantly reduce arthropod populations. Incorrect Options: B. Chemical control – This is incorrect. While chemical control (such as insecticides) can be effective in the short term, it is often more expensive due to the need for repeated application and the purchase of chemicals. It can also lead to resistance in pest populations and negative environmental effects, making it a less sustainable solution in the long run. C. Biological control – This is incorrect. Biological control involves the introduction of natural predators or parasites to control arthropods. While it can be effective in certain contexts, it often requires time to establish, and the initial costs may be higher than environmental control. Additionally, biological control may not always work effectively across all regions or pest species. D. Genetic control – This is incorrect. Genetic control involves modifying the genetic makeup of a species, often through techniques like sterilization or genetic modification. While promising, it is still in experimental stages in many areas and can be expensive to implement. This makes it a less cost-effective approach compared to simpler environmental controls.

questions.text: Flight range for aedes mosquito is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 100 meters 100 meters – This is correct. The Aedes mosquito typically has a flight range of up to 100 meters from its breeding site. These mosquitoes are generally not strong fliers, and while they can travel longer distances, their primary activity occurs within a short radius of their breeding site. This characteristic is important when controlling the spread of diseases like dengue, chikungunya, and Zika, as it helps target localized interventions. Incorrect Options: A. 10 meters – This is incorrect. While Aedes mosquitoes are usually found within a few meters of their breeding sites, their range can extend further, up to 100 meters. A range of 10 meters would be too short to account for their typical movement patterns. C. 400 meters – This is incorrect. A flight range of 400 meters is too far for Aedes mosquitoes, as they typically remain within a 100-meter radius of their breeding areas. Longer distances are more typical for other mosquito species, like Culex mosquitoes. D. 11 KMS – This is incorrect. A flight range of 11 kilometers is unrealistic for Aedes mosquitoes. This distance is far greater than what these mosquitoes can cover, as they are relatively weak fliers compared to other mosquito species.

choices.text: It is used as an anti-adult measure
It is more effective against anopheles
In usual doses also it harms fish man and domestic animal

questions.text: True about paris green for mosquito control is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It is more effective against Anopheles It is more effective against Anopheles – This is correct. Paris Green (copper(II) acetoarsenite) is a compound traditionally used in mosquito control, especially effective against Anopheles mosquitoes, which are the vectors of malaria. It works as a larvicide and is more effective in controlling the larvae of Anopheles mosquitoes compared to other mosquito species. Incorrect Options: A. It is used as an anti-adult measure – This is incorrect. Paris Green is not typically used for adult mosquito control; instead, it is more commonly used to target mosquito larvae in water sources. It is a larvicide rather than an adulticide. C. In usual doses, also it harms fish, man, and domestic animals – This is incorrect. While Paris Green is toxic, when used in careful, controlled doses for mosquito larval control, it generally does not harm fish, humans, or domestic animals. However, it can be harmful if misused or applied in excessive amounts. D. It is a nerve poison – This is incorrect. Paris Green is not classified as a nerve poison. Its toxicity is primarily due to its arsenic content, which acts as a general poison, inhibiting various biological processes rather than affecting the nervous system directly like some nerve poisons (e.g., organophosphates).

questions.text: All of the following methods are anti larval measure except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pyrethrum Pyrethrum – This is correct because Pyrethrum is not an anti-larval measure. It is an adulticide, meaning it is used to kill adult mosquitoes rather than targeting their larvae. Pyrethrum, derived from chrysanthemum flowers, is commonly used in mosquito fogging and spraying to kill adult mosquitoes, not to control larvae in water. Incorrect Options: A. Intermittent irrigation – This is incorrect. Intermittent irrigation is an anti-larval measure used to control mosquito larvae in agricultural fields. By periodically flooding and draining fields, it disrupts the breeding cycle of mosquitoes, making it less conducive for larvae to develop. B. Paris green – This is incorrect. Paris Green is a chemical compound used as a larvicide to control mosquito larvae. It is effective in targeting the larvae in water bodies and preventing them from maturing into adult mosquitoes. C.
