Gambusia affinis – This is incorrect. Gambusia affinis, also known as the mosquito fish, is used as a biological control agent for mosquitoes. These fish eat mosquito larvae, helping to reduce the mosquito population in water bodies, making it an effective anti-larval measure.

questions.text: Organosphosphate insecticides are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dieldrin A. Dieldrin – This is correct because Dieldrin is not an organophosphate insecticide. It is a chlorinated hydrocarbon (also known as an organochlorine), not an organophosphate. Dieldrin was used historically for insect control, particularly in agriculture, but it is now banned in many countries due to its persistence in the environment and toxicity. Incorrect Options: B. Fenthion – This is incorrect. Fenthion is an organophosphate insecticide. It is used to control a variety of pests, including mosquitoes and fruit flies, by inhibiting cholinesterase, an enzyme essential for nerve function. C. Diazinon – This is incorrect. Diazinon is an organophosphate insecticide commonly used for agricultural and household pest control. Like other organophosphates, it works by interfering with the nervous system of insects. D. Chlorpyrifos – This is incorrect. Chlorpyrifos is another organophosphate insecticide, widely used for pest control in agriculture, on lawns, and for household pests. It also works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, a key enzyme in nerve function.

choices.text: Use of bed nets for mosquito

questions.text: All of the following are deliberate measures of mosquito control except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Use of alkaline soap water Use of alkaline soap water – This is correct because alkaline soap water is not a deliberate or conventional measure for controlling mosquitoes. While soap and other detergents can sometimes be used to break the surface tension of water, making it less suitable for mosquito larvae, it's not a standard or widely recommended approach for mosquito control. Deliberate mosquito control usually involves more targeted methods like larvicides, community involvement, or physical barriers like bed nets. Incorrect Options: B. Use of larvicidal agents – This is incorrect because the use of larvicidal agents is a deliberate and common method of mosquito control. Larvicides target mosquito larvae in water sources, preventing them from maturing into adult mosquitoes. C. Community participation – This is incorrect because community participation is a key and effective measure in mosquito control. Educating communities about eliminating breeding sites, using nets, and improving sanitation are all ways in which communities actively contribute to mosquito control. D. Use of bed nets for mosquito – This is incorrect because using bed nets is a highly recommended and deliberate measure for controlling mosquitoes, especially in areas where diseases like malaria are prevalent. Bed nets, particularly those treated with insecticide, provide a physical barrier to prevent mosquitoes from biting during sleep.

questions.text: Vectors do not transmit infection by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ingestion Ingestion – This is correct because ingestion is not a common method by which vectors transmit infections. Vectors typically transmit pathogens through physical contact, regurgitation, contamination of body fluids, or by mechanical means, not by ingesting the pathogens themselves and passing them on to humans or other animals. Pathogens are typically transmitted through the bite of the vector or through bodily fluids, not through ingestion. Incorrect Options: B. Regurgitation – This is incorrect because regurgitation is a well-known method of transmission for many vectors, especially mosquitoes. For example, mosquitoes can regurgitate the pathogen from their stomachs into the bite wound, thereby transmitting diseases like malaria or dengue. C. Rubbing – This is incorrect because rubbing can also be a mode of transmission for certain vectors, such as lice or fleas. When these vectors move across the skin or body, they may transfer pathogens from one host to another by contact, or rubbing, on the surface. D. Contamination with body fluids – This is incorrect because contamination with body fluids is another common mechanism of disease transmission. For instance, ticks can spread Lyme disease through contact with infected body fluids, or fleas can spread plague by contaminating open wounds with infected blood.

questions.text: Least toxic organophosphorus compound is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Malathion Malathion – This is correct because malathion is considered one of the least toxic organophosphates. It has a relatively low toxicity to humans and animals compared to other organophosphorus compounds. Malathion is commonly used in agriculture and pest control because it degrades quickly in the environment and has less potential for bioaccumulation. Incorrect Options: A. DDT – This is incorrect because DDT (Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) is not an organophosphorus compound, but rather a chlorinated hydrocarbon. DDT is highly toxic to many forms of wildlife, particularly aquatic organisms, and its persistence in the environment has led to environmental and health concerns. B. Paris green – This is incorrect because Paris green is a copper(II) acetoarsenite, which is a very toxic compound used primarily as an insecticide and rodenticide. It contains arsenic, making it much more toxic than organophosphates like malathion. D. Parathion – This is incorrect because parathion is a highly toxic organophosphorus compound. It is much more toxic than malathion and can cause serious health effects even at low exposure levels. It has been largely restricted or banned in many countries due to its toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following statement regarding DDT is false:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Immediately kills the prey Immediately kills the prey – This is false because DDT does not immediately kill the prey. It acts as a contact poison, meaning it does not instantly kill insects but rather interferes with their nervous system, which leads to paralysis and eventual death after some time. The onset of death can take several hours to a day depending on the organism. Incorrect Options: A. Pyrethrum has synergistic action – This is true. Pyrethrum (a natural insecticide derived from chrysanthemums) is often used in combination with DDT because it has synergistic action. This means pyrethrum enhances the effectiveness of DDT, allowing for better pest control. B. It is a contact poison – This is true. DDT works as a contact poison, meaning it needs to make physical contact with the pest (typically through the insect’s outer body) to be effective. Once it comes into contact with the insect, it disrupts the nervous system, causing paralysis and death. D. Residual effect lasts 18 months – This is true. DDT has a long residual effect, meaning it remains effective for a long time after application, potentially up to 18 months or even longer in some conditions. This long-lasting property makes it effective in controlling pests over an extended period.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is transmitted globally by anopheles, culex and aedes mosquitoes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Filariasis Filariasis – This disease is transmitted by several species of mosquitoes, including Anopheles, Culex, and Aedes. The parasite causing filariasis (such as Wuchereria bancrofti) is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected mosquitoes. Different mosquito species can serve as vectors depending on the geographical region. Incorrect Options: A. Malaria – Malaria is primarily transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions. Culex and Aedes do not transmit malaria. B. Yellow fever – Yellow fever is primarily transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. While Culex mosquitoes can sometimes play a role in the transmission of other diseases, they are not responsible for yellow fever. C. Dengue fever – Dengue fever is mainly transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus. Culex and Anopheles mosquitoes are not involved in the transmission of dengue.

questions.text: Percentage of para – para isomer in DDT is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 70-80% 70-80% – The para-para isomer of DDT is the most biologically active form of DDT and makes up 70-80% of the DDT mixture. This isomer is the primary form responsible for the insecticidal activity of DDT, making it the dominant isomer in the formulation. Incorrect Options: A. 20-30% – This is too low a percentage to represent the para-para isomer in DDT. It is the other isomers (such as the ortho-para or meta-para isomers) that may make up smaller proportions in the mixture. B. 40-50% – This is also incorrect. While the para-para isomer is abundant in DDT, it is present in much higher percentages, typically in the 70-80% range. C. 60-70% – This is close, but the more accurate range for the para-para isomer is 70-80%, not 60-70%.

questions.text: Mineral oils are used in mosquito control measure as a:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Larvicide Larvicide – Mineral oils are used in mosquito control primarily as larvicides. They work by forming a thin film on the water surface, which suffocates the mosquito larvae by preventing them from breathing. Mineral oils do not kill the larvae directly but disrupt their ability to survive and develop. Incorrect Options: A. Personal protection method – Mineral oils are not used for personal protection; they are applied to water sources to target mosquito larvae, not directly to individuals to ward off mosquitoes. C. Adulticide – Mineral oils are not typically used to kill adult mosquitoes. Adulticides are chemicals designed to kill adult mosquitoes, and while mineral oils may have some effect on adult mosquitoes, they are primarily known as larvicides. D. Space spray – Space sprays are chemicals used in aerosolized form to kill adult mosquitoes in the air. Mineral oils are not used in space spraying applications but are instead applied to water for larvae control.

questions.text: The anopheles species most commonly found in coastal regions is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anopheles stephensi Anopheles stephensi – This species is commonly found in urban areas and coastal regions, especially in tropical and subtropical environments. It is a major vector of malaria in these areas and has adapted well to human habitation, making it prevalent in coastal regions. Incorrect Options: A. Anopheles philippinensis – This species is primarily found in Southeast Asia, particularly in the Philippines, but it is not specifically associated with coastal regions. C. Anopheles fluviatilis – This species is more commonly found in riverine and freshwater habitats rather than coastal areas. It is found in regions like India, but it is not specifically a coastal species. D. Anopheles minimus – This species is more common in forested and rural areas rather than coastal regions. It is found in parts of Southeast Asia, particularly in areas with more vegetation, rather than coastal habitats.

questions.text: Most efficient anti larval measure to prevent urban malaria is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cover overhead tanks properly Cover overhead tanks properly – The most efficient anti-larval measure for preventing urban malaria is to ensure that overhead water tanks are properly covered. This prevents mosquitoes from accessing the water to lay eggs, thus breaking the life cycle of the malaria-transmitting mosquitoes like Anopheles. Since these tanks are common in urban areas and can easily become breeding grounds for mosquitoes, proper covering is a highly effective measure. Incorrect Options: A. Clean draining and sewerage system – While cleaning drains and maintaining sewerage systems is important for general public health and preventing the spread of various diseases, it is not as directly effective in preventing urban malaria as covering water tanks. Mosquitoes breed in stagnant water, and sewerage systems are less of a breeding ground compared to improperly covered water tanks. C. Filling cesspools and ditches – Filling cesspools and ditches can be an effective measure in reducing mosquito breeding in certain environments. However, in urban settings, where overhead water tanks are more prevalent, the direct impact of filling ditches may not be as significant in preventing urban malaria. D. Cover pits – While covering pits can prevent mosquito breeding in specific places, the most common breeding grounds in urban areas are water storage tanks. Thus, the impact of this measure is more limited compared to ensuring that tanks are properly covered.

questions.text: The most prevalent mosquito - born viral disease in India:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dengue fever A. Dengue fever – Dengue fever is the most prevalent mosquito-borne viral disease in India. It is caused by the dengue virus, which is primarily transmitted by the Aedes mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti. In recent years, the number of dengue cases in India has been on the rise, especially during the monsoon season, making it the most widespread and significant mosquito-borne viral disease in the country. Incorrect Options: B. Japanese B encephalitis – While Japanese B encephalitis is a serious mosquito-borne viral disease in India, especially in rural areas, it is less prevalent than dengue fever. The disease is primarily transmitted by the Culex mosquitoes, and although it remains a public health concern, its overall incidence is lower compared to dengue. C. Filariasis – Filariasis, caused by parasitic worms and transmitted by Culex mosquitoes, is a major health issue in India. However, it is a parasitic disease, not a viral one. While it is endemic in certain parts of the country, it is not as widespread in terms of viral transmission when compared to dengue fever. D. Chikungunya – Chikungunya, caused by the chikungunya virus and transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, has also been a significant concern in India, with outbreaks occurring from time to time. However, dengue fever remains the most prevalent mosquito-borne viral disease.

questions.text: Best way to control houseflies:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Eliminate breeding places Eliminate breeding places – The best way to control houseflies is to eliminate their breeding sites. Houseflies breed in decaying organic matter, such as garbage, feces, and rotting food. By keeping the environment clean, managing waste properly, and removing potential breeding sites, you can significantly reduce the fly population. This method addresses the root cause of the problem and is more effective in the long term compared to other control methods. Incorrect Options: B. Insecticide spray – While insecticide sprays can provide immediate relief by killing adult houseflies, they do not address the source of the problem. They can be harmful to humans, pets, and the environment, and houseflies may develop resistance to the insecticides over time, making this an insufficient long-term solution. C. Bed Net use – Bed nets are effective in preventing mosquito bites, but they are not useful for controlling houseflies, as houseflies do not typically bite humans. Bed nets do not prevent houseflies from entering a room or breeding indoors. D. Paris green – Paris green is a pesticide primarily used for controlling pests in agricultural settings and is not suitable or effective for controlling houseflies. It can also be toxic to humans and animals, making it an inappropriate method for housefly control in domestic environments

questions.text: Number of holes per square inch of a standard mosquito net is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 150 150 – A standard mosquito net typically has around 150 holes per square inch. This mesh density is effective in preventing mosquitoes from passing through the net while still allowing air circulation, ensuring both protection and comfort. The fine mesh helps prevent even smaller mosquitoes from entering and biting while the person is inside the net. Incorrect Options: A. 100 – A net with only 100 holes per square inch would have a coarser mesh and may not be as effective at blocking mosquitoes, especially the smaller varieties. It would allow more air flow but would be less protective. C. 250 – A net with 250 holes per square inch would have an even finer mesh than the standard 150 holes per square inch. While it could theoretically offer more protection, it would reduce airflow and could be less comfortable, making it less ideal for general use in most climates. D. 175 – While 175 holes per square inch is a finer mesh, it is not the standard mesh density used in typical mosquito nets, and it doesn't provide the optimal balance of protection and comfort

questions.text: Paris Green is used to eliminate the larva of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anopheles Anopheles – Paris Green is a type of copper acetoarsenite, historically used as an insecticide to control the larvae of Anopheles mosquitoes. These mosquitoes are the primary vectors of malaria, and Paris Green was traditionally used to target their larvae in breeding areas like stagnant water bodies. It is effective against Anopheles larvae, helping reduce malaria transmission. Incorrect Options: B. Culex – While Paris Green can theoretically affect the larvae of various mosquito species, it is not commonly used specifically for controlling Culex larvae. Culex mosquitoes are known to transmit diseases like West Nile virus and filariasis, but Paris Green is not the primary larvicide used against them. C. Aedes – Aedes mosquitoes, which are vectors of diseases like dengue and Zika, are generally controlled using different methods and insecticides. Paris Green is not commonly used to target Aedes larvae. D. Mansonoides – Mansonia mosquitoes breed in aquatic vegetation, and while Paris Green might affect their larvae, it is not the most widely used method for controlling them. Other specific larvicides are more effective for controlling Mansonoides mosquitoes.

questions.text: Which of the following type of mosquito can be controlled by removing and destroying the aquatic plants by herbicides?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mansonia Mansonia – Mansonia mosquitoes breed in areas where there are dense aquatic plants, such as submerged vegetation. The larvae of Mansonia mosquitoes are known to attach themselves to these plants to feed and grow. By removing and destroying the aquatic plants using herbicides, the breeding sites for Mansonia mosquitoes can be eliminated, effectively controlling their population. This method is commonly employed in areas with Mansonia mosquitoes, which are responsible for transmitting diseases like lymphatic filariasis. Incorrect Options: A. Aedes – Aedes mosquitoes typically breed in small, clean water containers or artificial containers like tires, flowerpots, and discarded items. They do not rely on aquatic plants, so removing or destroying aquatic plants will not have an impact on their population. B. Culex – Culex mosquitoes tend to breed in standing water such as ditches, gutters, and sewage systems, and their larvae are not dependent on aquatic plants. Thus, destroying aquatic plants would not be an effective method for controlling Culex mosquitoes. D. Anopheles – While Anopheles mosquitoes breed in stagnant water bodies, they generally do not rely on aquatic plants for their larvae to develop. Removing aquatic plants is not a primary method for controlling Anopheles mosquitoes, which are better managed through the use of larvicides or draining water sources.

questions.text: Most hazardous pesticide colour coding
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Red Red – In pesticide color coding, red is used to indicate the most hazardous pesticides. These are chemicals that pose the highest risk to human health, animals, and the environment. The red color coding serves as a warning to users, ensuring that the proper precautions are taken when handling these products. Pesticides with red coding typically require the highest level of safety measures and protective equipment during use. Incorrect Options: B. Green – Green coding indicates that the pesticide is relatively low in toxicity and is considered safer for human use. These are typically non-chemical or less hazardous products that can be used with fewer risks compared to more hazardous chemicals. C. Yellow – Yellow is used for moderately toxic pesticides. While they are more dangerous than green-coded chemicals, they are not as hazardous as red-coded ones. Safety precautions are still necessary, but they are less stringent than for red-coded pesticides. D. Black – Black does not generally represent a specific color coding for pesticide hazard levels in the standard classification system. It is not used to indicate the hazard level of pesticides in most regulatory systems.

questions.text: Image shown below belongs to which micronutrient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fluorine The image likely depicts dental fluorosis, which is caused by excessive fluoride intake. Fluoride is an essential micronutrient that helps prevent dental caries, but excessive consumption can lead to mottling of teeth, characterized by white, yellow, or brown discoloration. This is a classic feature of fluorosis, which is why fluorine is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: Iodine (A) - Incorrect Iodine deficiency leads to goiter (thyroid swelling) and hypothyroidism, not dental fluorosis. Calcium (C) - Incorrect Calcium is essential for bone and teeth strength, but deficiency causes rickets (in children) and osteomalacia (in adults) rather than fluorosis. Iron (D) - Incorrect Iron deficiency causes anemia, leading to pallor, fatigue, and spoon-shaped nails (koilonychia) but does not cause dental fluorosis.

questions.text: Lead toxicity is an important environmental disease and its effects on the human body are devastating. The major environmental source of lead absorbed in the human blood stream in adults is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Air) In adults, the major environmental source of lead exposure is air, primarily due to occupational exposure in industries such as battery manufacturing, mining, smelting, and construction. Key Points About Lead Exposure in Adults: Inhalation of lead fumes or dust is the primary route of exposure in workplace settings (e.g., welding, painting, demolition, and manufacturing). Airborne lead particles are absorbed rapidly through the lungs and enter the bloodstream, leading to elevated blood lead levels (BLLs). Chronic exposure can cause neurological, cardiovascular, renal, and reproductive toxicity. Incorrect Options: B. Water – Incorrect While lead contamination in water (due to lead pipes or plumbing systems) is a significant source of exposure, it primarily affects infants and children rather than adults in occupational settings. Lead leaches into drinking water, especially in older homes with lead pipes or soldered plumbing systems, but it is not the major source of lead absorption in adults. C. Lead-based paint – Incorrect Lead-based paint is a major source of lead poisoning in children, not adults. Ingestion of lead-contaminated dust from deteriorating paint is the main exposure route for young children who engage in hand-to-mouth activity. Adults are usually exposed to lead-based paint in occupational settings (e.g., painters, renovators), but air exposure remains the dominant source. D. Food – Incorrect Lead can contaminate food through contaminated soil, storage in lead-glazed pottery, or food packaging, but it is not the primary source of lead toxicity in adults. In developed countries, strict regulations limit lead contamination in food.

choices.text: Decreased incidence of osteoporosis in elderly females
Decrease in cases of food poisoning

questions.text: Hard water contains salts of calcium and magnesium, hard water consumption is associated with which of the following beneficial health effects?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hard water is water that has high mineral content. Hard water is formed when water percolates through deposits of limestone, chalk or gypsum which are largely made up of calcium and magnesium carbonates, bicarbonates and sulfates. In domestic settings, hard water is often indicated by a lack of foam formation when soap is agitated in water, and by the formation of limescale in kettles and water heaters. Wherever water hardness is a concern, water softening is commonly used to reduce hard water's adverse effects. Hard drinking water may have moderate health benefits. An inverse or protective association of water hardness with cardiovascular mortality is reported in studies. In studies involving very large geographical areas, there was a strong tendency to observe lower cardiovascular mortality with increasing hardness of drinking water sources.
